definitions.definition: an accident in which a vehicle hits something, for example another vehicle, usually causing damage and often injuring or killing the passengers

examples.text: a **car/plane crash**
A man has been arrested in connection with a **fatal crash** on the M4 motorway.
It is not clear what **caused the crash**.
A girl was **killed** yesterday **in a crash** involving a stolen car.
34 people **died in** the train **crash**.
There were no other vehicles **involved in the crash**.
Mechanical failures were to blame for the crash of the helicopter.
She had survived a plane crash.
He had survived a spectacular crash in a truck race.
She was killed in a train crash.
In thirty years of driving he had never had a crash.
She swerved to avoid a crash.
The crash claimed three lives.
a crash involving two cars and a bus
a fiery crash which killed the pilot
a major air crash

definitions.definition: a sudden loud noise made, for example, by something falling or breaking

examples.text: The tree fell with a great crash.
The first distant crash of thunder shook the air.
She heard the crash of shattering glass as the vehicles collided.
The bike hit the street and made a loud crash.
The plates fell to the floor with an almighty crash.
There was a sickening crash as his head hit the ground.
the crash of the waves

definitions.definition: a sudden serious fall in the price or value of something; the occasion when a business, etc. fails

examples.text: Some economists have been predicting another crash for years.
the 2008 **stock market crash**
the crash of 2008
a crash in share prices

definitions.definition: a sudden failure of a machine or system, especially of a computer or computer system

examples.text: Users won't lose important data if a hardware problem causes a crash.
a computer crash
A systems crash in the morning and a bomb scare in the afternoon provided enough excitement for one day.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: imitative, perhaps partly suggested by craze and dash.
